timeline.bodyText: This is ok but I would just pass System.getEnv() map. Gives a bit more test coverage
timeline.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText:
Prefer guava (I think this is leaked into our test classpath but in general we don't use Apache commons)
https://guava.dev/releases/21.0/api/docs/com/google/common/io/Files.html#write-java.lang.CharSequence-java.io.File-java.nio.charset.Charset-
timeline.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: I realized we can use Guava's Files readalllines if we want.
timeline.author: anuraaga
anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: Just do assertThat(metadata).containsExactly for all the map assertions in the PR
timeline.author: anuraaga

timeline.bodyText: According to the specifications there is not container.id field. Do you have a use case for this field?
timeline.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText:
Ah nice eyes didn't notice this isn't semanticattributes.
@wangzlei shouldn't this be container name and the above hostname?
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: We should definitely only be putting official semantic attributes into the Resource. And, the keys should be being kept in the io.opentelemetry.sdk.resource.ResourceConstants class.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText:
Yeah I think we'll look at proposing container.id as a semantic convention, it seems to be missing (name is usually human readable not the ID).
But wanted to confirm, you think there should only be official semantic attributes here? What about vendor-specific resource attributes? For example, AWS services have a log group ID used for correlation, which is sort of independent from other semantic values like the service name. I was sort of expecting we'd add this as a non-standard attribute on the resource at some point.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Actually nevermind, I guess this log group I'm thinking of is x-ray specific, but not for general AWS users. So yeah doesn't belong here most likely :)
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText:
Just realize that my previous reply was not sent out.
Refer to docker documentation Container identification, Container's full-id, short-id and name are equivalent in docker CLI like 'docker info '. name is usually human readable and can be changed by command 'docker rename' during runtime.
I will cut a PR for adding container.id in semantic conversions. Thanks.
replies.author: wangzlei

timeline.message: change to Guava Files, change Map to Attributes

timeline.bodyText: Avoid unnecessary null checks, sysEnv can't be null (unless a unit test passes it randomly which is something we don't need to worry about in business logic)
timeline.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: removed null check and synEnv null test
replies.author: wangzlei

timeline.bodyText: This class is not used after the removal of container.id. I would remove it and reintroduce it when your suggested spec changes are accepted :)
timeline.author: thisthat

replies.bodyText: I agree. let's remove it if we're not using it.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: removed DockerHelper and unit test from PR
replies.author: wangzlei

timeline.bodyText: This makes me think that a "merge" function might be useful on the Attributes, like we have on the Resource itself.
timeline.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: A ready-to-use merge would be better. One more thing I found in unit test is if builder set the duplicated key, the final Attributes has the fist one but not the last one. It seems wired that usually the last one can override the first. Please see my AwsResourceTest.java
replies.author: wangzlei

replies.bodyText: Yes, we currently keep the first, if there are duplicates. If you think this is not correct, please file an issue!
replies.author: jkwatson

timeline.message: Remove DockerHelper until has container.id in sematic conventions.
